supplierManager.cardDescription: Manage time-to-failure data for each piece of equipment.
supplierManager.hasSuspensionsDescription: Right-censored data (items that did not fail).
supplierManager.isGroupedDescription: Multiple items with the same failure time.

probabilityPlot.cardDescription: Goodness-of-fit analysis. The closer the points are to the fitted line, the better the model fits.
probabilityPlot.noData: Add or select equipment with the "{{paperType}}" distribution to see the chart.

limitReached.title: Limit Reached
limitReached.description: You can compare a maximum of 5 equipments at a time.

invalidData.noData: At least one valid data point is required for analysis.

insufficientData.title: Insufficient Data
insufficientData.description: Please enter at least two valid failure times.
insufficientData.budgetSource: At least 2 failure points (F) are required to calculate Beta and Eta parameters.

missingParams.title: Missing Parameters
missingParams.dispersion: Please fill in all fields for the dispersion simulation.
missingParams.budget: Please fill in all fields for the budget calculation.
missingParams.competing: Add at least one failure mode and fill in the forecast period.

calculationError.title: Calculation Error
calculationError.description: Could not estimate Beta and Eta from the source data.

emptyPopulation.title: Empty Population
emptyPopulation.description: No items in the in-service population to calculate the budget.

emptyMode.title: Empty Failure Mode
emptyMode.description: All failure modes must have at least one failure time.

distributionWizard.title: Distribution Wizard - {{supplierName}}
distributionWizard.description: Analyze which probability distribution best fits your equipment data.
distributionWizard.howTitle: üîç How we choose the best distribution
distributionWizard.howIntro: The tool evaluates different statistical distributions to find which model best represents the equipment's failure behavior. The main criterion is:
distributionWizard.howLkv: Indicates how well the model fits the data. Higher (less negative) values mean a better statistical fit.
distributionWizard.howR2: The displayed R¬≤ is only for visual reference on the probability plot, but it does not determine which distribution is better. It serves only as a graphical reference.
distributionWizard.explanationLognormal: The Lognormal distribution showed the highest LKV ({{lkv}}), indicating the best statistical fit for this equipment's failure and suspension data. This model correctly captures the variability and long tail observed in the failure times.
distributionWizard.explanationWeibull: The Weibull distribution showed the highest LKV ({{lkv}}), indicating the best statistical fit for this equipment's data. The beta parameter reveals the failure rate behavior over time.

charts.noData: Add equipment data to see the charts.

reliability.title: Reliability: R(t)
reliability.description: Probability of operating correctly until time t.

failureProb.title: Failure Probability: F(t)
failureProb.description: Probability of failing before time t.

pdf.title: Probability Density: f(t)
pdf.description: Relative probability of failure at time t.

failureRate.title: Failure Rate: Œª(t)
failureRate.description: Instantaneous probability of failure at time t.

weibullAnalysis.cardDescription: Interpret Beta (shape) and Eta (life) parameters to understand the failure mode and lifespan of your equipment.

infantMortality.interpretation: Focus on improving quality, commissioning, and acceptance testing.

usefulLife.interpretation: Consider time-based Preventive Maintenance (PM) or cost-benefit analyses.

wearOut.interpretation: Ideal scenario for Predictive Maintenance (PdM) as there is a clear wear pattern.

eta.description: This is the time at which 63.2% of the component population will have failed. It's a crucial reliability milestone for planning.

bathtub.cardDescription: Visualize failure points throughout the component's life cycle.
bathtub.noData: Add equipment data to see the analysis.

aiAnalysis.addEquipment: Add equipment data to enable analysis.

risk.cardDescription: Use historical failure data to identify the most significant risk factors contributing to failures.
risk.pending: Analyzing historical data... This may take a moment.
risk.noFactors: No significant risk factors were identified.

comprehensive.cardDescription: Generate a detailed technical analysis comparing all equipment across the four main reliability charts.
comprehensive.pending: Generating comparative analysis... This may take a moment.
comprehensive.doneDescription: Below is a technical analysis for each chart, comparing the performance of the selected equipment.

monteCarlo.cardDescription: Select the type of simulation you want to perform.
monteCarlo.waiting: Waiting for parameters to start the simulation.

errors.contour: Could not calculate confidence contour. Check if the data is suitable for a Weibull analysis.
errors.competing: Could not analyze competing modes. Check the input data.

confidence.title: Confidence Bounds
confidence.cardDescription: Calculate the bounds based on manually entered failure data.

results.title: Calculated Values for t = {{time}}
results.description: Point estimates and confidence bounds for Reliability and Failure Probability.
results.interpretation1: For a time of {{time}} hours, the estimated failure probability (best guess) is {{prob}}.
results.interpretation2: The {{level}}% confidence interval means we can state with this certainty that the true failure probability of the equipment is between {{lower}} (optimistic scenario) and {{upper}} (pessimistic scenario).
results.interpretation3: A wide confidence interval suggests greater uncertainty, often due to a small sample size.
results.interpretationError: Could not calculate interpretation. Check the input data and confidence bounds.

dispersion.title: Parameter Dispersion
dispersion.cardDescription: Simulate the variability of the Beta and Eta parameters.
dispersion.betaDescription: Defines the failure mode. <1: early; ‚âà1: random; >1: wear-out.
dispersion.etaDescription: The time at which 63.2% of the population will have failed. Indicates useful life.
dispersion.sampleSizeDescription: No. of data points in each test. Larger samples yield more stable estimates.
dispersion.simulationCountDescription: No. of times the simulation is run. Increasing reduces result uncertainty.

contour.title: Contour Plot
contour.cardDescription: Calculate the likelihood ratio confidence ellipse.

results.title: Parameter Confidence Bounds
results.description: Maximum Likelihood Estimate (MLE) and the confidence bounds for each parameter.

budget.title: Spares Budget
budget.cardDescription: Estimate future failures and costs for a population of in-service items.
budget.sourceDataDescription: Data to estimate Beta and Eta parameters. Use [Time] [F/S].
budget.extractToastDescription: Suspension items have been added to the in-service population.

results.paramsDescription: These are the shape (Beta) and scale (Eta) parameters calculated from your data.
results.budgetDescription: Number of expected failures and associated costs for the in-service population over the defined period.
results.footer: Plan your budget based on the Upper Bound (UB) to ensure a service level of {{level}}%.
results.interpretation1: The Median is your best estimate, the most likely number of failures based on the data. It's the starting point for planning.
results.interpretation2: The Confidence Bounds (LB and UB) quantify the forecast's uncertainty, based on the {{level}}% confidence level. They define a range where the actual number of failures is likely to fall.
results.interpretation3: Lower Bound (LB): The optimistic scenario. There is a low probability that the number of failures will be less than this value.
results.interpretation4: Upper Bound (UB): The pessimistic scenario and the most important for budgeting. To ensure an adequate service level and avoid stockouts, plan your spares budget based on this value.
results.interpretation5: The width of the interval (difference between UB and LB) reflects the quality of your data. More consistent and larger volumes of data generally result in a narrower confidence interval and a more precise forecast.
results.detailsDescription: This is the failure forecast for each group of items in your in-service population.

competing.title: Competing Modes
competing.cardDescription: Analyze the reliability of a system with multiple failure modes.

results.analysisDescription: Weibull parameters (MLE) calculated for each competing failure mode.
results.probDescription: Individual failure probability for each mode at the specified time.
results.criticalMode: The failure mode {{mode}} is the most critical, with the highest probability of occurrence.
results.tablesDescription: See how data is treated for each individual failure mode analysis. 'F' indicates a failure of the mode under analysis, and 'S' indicates a suspension (a failure of a competing mode).

simple.title: Times to Failure (TTF)
simple.description: Enter values separated by comma, space, or new line.
